Class InputDispatcher

Namespace
FlowGraph.Avalonia.Input
Assembly
FlowGraph.Avalonia.dll

Coordinates input handling between behaviors, processors, and the state machine.

public class InputDispatcher

object

object.ToString()

Remarks

The InputDispatcher is the central coordinator for the hybrid input architecture: 

               Input Event (PointerPressed, etc.)
                          │
                          ▼
             ┌───────────────────────┐
             │    InputDispatcher    │
             └───────────────────────┘
                          │
      ┌───────────────────┼───────────────────┐
      ▼                   ▼                   ▼
┌──────────┐       ┌────────────┐      ┌──────────┐
│ Behaviors │       │ HitTester  │      │ State    │
│ (before)  │       │            │      │ Machine  │
└──────────┘       └────────────┘      └──────────┘
      │                   │                   │
      │                   ▼                   │
      │            GraphHitTestResult         │
      │                   │                   │
      │                   ▼                   │
      │         ┌─────────────────┐           │
      │         │ InputProcessor  │           │
      │         │ (by hit type)   │           │
      │         └─────────────────┘           │
      │                   │                   │
      │                   ▼                   │
      │            State Transition?──────────┘
      │                   │
      ▼                   ▼
┌──────────┐        Result/New State
│ Behaviors │
│ (after)   │
└──────────┘

Performance Optimizations (Gemini):

  • HitTargetType is a [Flags] enum for O(1) bitmask checks
  • Processor lookup uses pre-computed Dictionary for O(1) dispatch
  • Behaviors support state-aware filtering via ActiveInStates
  • Processor list sorted once on registration, not on every dispatch

Pointer Capture (Critical for Drag Operations): When a processor starts a drag operation (e.g., NodeProcessor → DraggingState), it MUST capture the pointer via e.Pointer.Capture(control). This ensures the interaction state continues to receive events even if the mouse moves outside the element's visual bounds. Without capture, fast mouse movements would cause hit tests to return "Canvas" instead of the element being dragged.

Methods

DispatchKeyDown(InputStateContext, KeyEventArgs, string)

Dispatches a key down event for keyboard shortcuts.

public StateTransitionResult DispatchKeyDown(InputStateContext context, KeyEventArgs e, string currentStateName = "Idle")

Parameters

context InputStateContext

The input state context.

e KeyEventArgs

The key event args.

currentStateName string

Name of the current state (for behavior filtering).

Returns

StateTransitionResult

Remarks

Keyboard events don't use processors - they're handled globally. Note: Behavior keyboard hooks are not currently implemented as they require a framework-agnostic key representation. This handles keyboard shortcuts directly.

Dispatches a pointer moved event through the full pipeline.

DispatchPointerWheel(InputStateContext, PointerWheelEventArgs, Point, string)

Dispatches a pointer wheel event for viewport zoom/pan.

public StateTransitionResult DispatchPointerWheel(InputStateContext context, PointerWheelEventArgs e, Point viewportPosition, string currentStateName = "Idle")

Parameters

context InputStateContext

The input state context.

e PointerWheelEventArgs

The wheel event args.

viewportPosition Point

Position in viewport coordinates.

currentStateName string

Name of the current state (for behavior filtering).

Returns

StateTransitionResult

Remarks

Unlike other pointer events, wheel events don't use hit testing or processors. They directly affect the viewport (zoom or pan) based on settings. Behaviors can still intercept or observe wheel events.
